title: ToolLifeEngine: Taylor Equation Verification
verdict: PASS — Taylor equation correctly implemented, 2 LOW findings

extended_taylor.description: Simplified extended Taylor applying feed/depth corrections independently from reference values. This is a reasonable approximation of the full extended Taylor: V*T^n*f^a*d^b = C_ext

findings.title: Extended Taylor exponents are hardcoded, not material-specific
findings.issue: Feed exponent a=0.35 and depth exponent b=0.2 are fixed constants. In practice, these vary by material (e.g., a=0.2-0.5 for different steel grades). The reference values (feed=0.2, depth=2.0) are also fixed.
findings.impact: Low — the corrections are secondary to the V-T relationship, and the fixed values are reasonable median estimates.
findings.fix: Accept a/b exponents as optional parameters in the TaylorCoefficients interface, or look them up from material registry.

findings.title: optimal_speed is a fixed 85% heuristic, not cost-derived
findings.issue: optimal_speed = cutting_speed * 0.85 is a crude heuristic. The actual minimum cost speed depends on tool cost, machine rate, and change time (Gilbert's equation). AdvancedCalculations.calculateMinimumCostSpeed implements the correct derivation.
findings.impact: Low — this is a quick estimate. The proper function exists in AdvancedCalculations.
findings.fix: Either remove optimal_speed from this function (it's misleading), or call calculateMinimumCostSpeed if cost params are available.
